Metric Spaces

When working with metric spaces, there are two main examples you want to have in mind:

  1. (R,∣ ⋅ ∣)\p{\R, \abs{\,\cdot\,}}(R,∣⋅∣), which is useful to have in the back of your mind when doing proofs for general metric spaces.
  2. (R2,Euclidean distance)\p{\R^2, \text{Euclidean distance}}(R2,Euclidean distance), which is useful when drawing pictures (this will be an especially helpful example when we get to point-set topology).
Definition (metric spaces)

Let XXX be a non-empty set. A function d ⁣:X×X→[0,∞)\func{d}{X \times X}{\pco{0, \infty}}d:X×X→[0,∞) is called a metric on XXX if:

  1. d(x,y)=0  ⟺  x=yd\p{x, y} = 0 \iff x = yd(x,y)=0⟺x=y
  2. (symmetry) d(x,y)=d(y,x)d\p{x, y} = d\p{y, x}d(x,y)=d(y,x)
  3. (triangle inequality) d(x,y)≤d(x,z)+d(z,y)d\p{x, y} \leq d\p{x, z} + d\p{z, y}d(x,y)≤d(x,z)+d(z,y)

The tuple (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) is called a metric space.

In analysis, one of the most important concepts is convergence, i.e., limits:

Definition

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space. We say that a sequence (xn)\p{x_n}(xn​) converges to xxx with respect to the metric ddd if lim⁡n→∞d(xn,x)=0\lim_{n\to\infty} d\p{x_n, x} = 0limn→∞​d(xn​,x)=0.

Equivalently, if for any ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, there exists NNN such that if n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, then d(xn,x)<εd\p{x_n, x} < \epsilond(xn​,x)<ε.

Motivation

Example 1.

Let X=C([0,1])X = C\p{\br{0, 1}}X=C([0,1]) be the set of continuous functions on the interval [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1]. We will consider two metrics on this set:

d1(f,g)=∫01∣f(x)−g(x)∣ dxd2(f,g)=sup⁡x∈[0,1]∣f(x)−g(x)∣\begin{aligned} d_1\p{f, g} &= \int_0^1 \abs{f\p{x} - g\p{x}} \,\diff{x} \\ d_2\p{f, g} &= \sup_{x \in \br{0,1}} \abs{f\p{x} - g\p{x}} \end{aligned}d1​(f,g)d2​(f,g)​=∫01​∣f(x)−g(x)∣dx=x∈[0,1]sup​∣f(x)−g(x)∣​

Consider the sequence fn(x)=xnf_n\p{x} = x^nfn​(x)=xn. In the first metric,

d1(fn,0)=∫01xn dx=1n+1→n→∞0.d_1\p{f_n, 0} = \int_0^1 x^n \,\diff{x} = \frac{1}{n + 1} \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} 0.d1​(fn​,0)=∫01​xndx=n+11​n→∞​0.

In the second metric,

d2(fn,0)=sup⁡x∈[0,1]xn=1.d_2\p{f_n, 0} = \sup_{x \in \br{0,1}} x^n = 1.d2​(fn​,0)=x∈[0,1]sup​xn=1.

Our calculations show that fnf_nfn​ converges to 000 with respect to d1d_1d1​ (which is called the L1L^1L1-metric), but it does not converge with respect to d2d_2d2​ (which is called the sup⁡\supsup-metric or L∞L^\inftyL∞-metric).

Moral: Different metrics capture different types of convergence.

In analysis, one of the central concepts is convergence, and metrics are an important way to describe the type of convergence we have.

Examples

Example 2.
(Exercise 1.1.10)

Let X=RnX = \R^nX=Rn and let

dℓ2(x,y)=(∑i=1n∣xi−yi∣2)1/2,dℓ∞(x,y)=sup⁡1≤i≤n∣xi−yi∣.\begin{aligned} d_{\ell^2}\p{x, y} &= \p{\sum_{i=1}^n \abs{x_i - y_i}^2}^{1/2}, \\ d_{\ell^\infty}\p{x, y} &= \sup_{1 \leq i \leq n} \abs{x_i - y_i}. \end{aligned}dℓ2​(x,y)dℓ∞​(x,y)​=(i=1∑n​∣xi​−yi​∣2)1/2,=1≤i≤nsup​∣xi​−yi​∣.​

Show that

1ndℓ2(x,y)≤dℓ∞(x,y)≤dℓ2(x,y).\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} d_{\ell^2}\p{x, y} \leq d_{\ell^\infty}\p{x, y} \leq d_{\ell^2}\p{x, y}.n​1​dℓ2​(x,y)≤dℓ∞​(x,y)≤dℓ2​(x,y).
Solution.

There are two inequalities to show:

1ndℓ2(x,y)≤dℓ∞(x,y)anddℓ∞(x,y)≤dℓ2(x,y).\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} d_{\ell^2}\p{x, y} \leq d_{\ell^\infty}\p{x, y} \quad\text{and}\quad d_{\ell^\infty}\p{x, y} \leq d_{\ell^2}\p{x, y}.n​1​dℓ2​(x,y)≤dℓ∞​(x,y)anddℓ∞​(x,y)≤dℓ2​(x,y).

Let's start with the first one. Notice that by definition of a supremum,

∣xi−yi∣≤dℓ∞(x,y)\abs{x_i - y_i} \leq d_{\ell^\infty}\p{x, y}∣xi​−yi​∣≤dℓ∞​(x,y)

for any 1≤i≤n1 \leq i \leq n1≤i≤n. Thus,

dℓ2(x,y)=(∑i=1n∣xi−yi∣2)1/2≤(∑i=1ndℓ∞(x,y)2)1/2=(ndℓ∞(x,y)2)1/2=ndℓ∞(x,y)  ⟹  1ndℓ2(x,y)≤dℓ∞(x,y),\begin{aligned} d_{\ell^2}\p{x, y} &= \p{\sum_{i=1}^n \abs{x_i - y_i}^2}^{1/2} \\ &\leq \p{\sum_{i=1}^n d_{\ell^\infty}\p{x, y}^2}^{1/2} \\ &= \p{n d_{\ell^\infty}\p{x, y}^2}^{1/2} \\ &= \sqrt{n} d_{\ell^\infty}\p{x, y} \\ \implies \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} d_{\ell^2}\p{x, y} &\leq d_{\ell^\infty}\p{x, y}, \end{aligned}dℓ2​(x,y)⟹n​1​dℓ2​(x,y)​=(i=1∑n​∣xi​−yi​∣2)1/2≤(i=1∑n​dℓ∞​(x,y)2)1/2=(ndℓ∞​(x,y)2)1/2=n​dℓ∞​(x,y)≤dℓ∞​(x,y),​

which proves the first inequality. For the second inequality, we want to prove a statement about a supremum-we want to show that

sup⁡1≤i≤n∣xi−yi∣≤dℓ2(x,y).\sup_{1 \leq i \leq n} \abs{x_i - y_i} \leq d_{\ell^2}\p{x, y}.1≤i≤nsup​∣xi​−yi​∣≤dℓ2​(x,y).

When you want to prove something like this, you almost never want to find an inequality with the supremum directly. Instead, you want to find an upper bound for every element you take the supremum of, i.e., you want to find an upper bound for ∣xk−yk∣\abs{x_k - y_k}∣xk​−yk​∣ that works for each 1≤k≤n1 \leq k \leq n1≤k≤n (I switched to kkk here since I want to use iii for the index in the sum):

∣xk−yk∣=(∣xk−yk∣2)1/2≤(∑i=1n∣xk−yk∣2)1/2=dℓ2(x,y).\begin{aligned} \abs{x_k - y_k} &= \p{\abs{x_k - y_k}^2}^{1/2} \\ &\leq \p{\sum_{i=1}^n \abs{x_k - y_k}^2}^{1/2} \\ &= d_{\ell^2}\p{x, y}. \end{aligned}∣xk​−yk​∣​=(∣xk​−yk​∣2)1/2≤(i=1∑n​∣xk​−yk​∣2)1/2=dℓ2​(x,y).​

Thus, dℓ2(x,y)d_{\ell^2}\p{x, y}dℓ2​(x,y) is an upper bound for the set {∣xi−yi∣∣1≤i≤n}\set{\abs{x_i - y_i} \mid 1 \leq i \leq n}{∣xi​−yi​∣∣1≤i≤n}, so because the supremum is the least upper bound, you immediately get

dℓ∞(x,y)=sup⁡1≤i≤n∣xi−yi∣≤dℓ2(x,y).d_{\ell^\infty}\p{x, y} = \sup_{1 \leq i \leq n} \abs{x_i - y_i} \leq d_{\ell^2}\p{x, y}.dℓ∞​(x,y)=1≤i≤nsup​∣xi​−yi​∣≤dℓ2​(x,y).
Example 3.
(Exercise 1.1.13)

Let XXX be any set, and let ddd be the discrete metric on XXX:

d(x,y)={0if x=y,1if x≠y.d\p{x, y} = \begin{cases} 0 & \text{if } x = y, \\ 1 & \text{if } x \neq y. \end{cases}d(x,y)={01​if x=y,if x=y.​

Show that (xn)\p{x_n}(xn​) converges to xxx with respect to the discrete metric if and only if there exists an NNN such that xn=xx_n = xxn​=x for all n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N.
Solution.

There are two implications to prove:

"  ⟸  \impliedby⟸"

Assume that there exists NNN such that xn=xx_n = xxn​=x for all n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N. Given any ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, if n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, then

d(xn,x)=d(x,x)=0<ε.d\p{x_n, x} = d\p{x, x} = 0 < \epsilon.d(xn​,x)=d(x,x)=0<ε.

Thus, (xn)\p{x_n}(xn​) converges to xxx with respect to the discrete metric. (We never used the fact that ddd is the discrete metric, so in this case, (xn)\p{x_n}(xn​) actually converges to xxx with respect to any metric.)

"  ⟹  \implies⟹"

Now assume that (xn)\p{x_n}(xn​) converges to xxx with respect to the discrete metric. This means that given any ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, there exists NNN such that if n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, then d(xn,x)<εd\p{x_n, x} < \epsilond(xn​,x)<ε.

Here, we will need to use the fact that ddd is the discrete metric: if we pick ε=12\epsilon = \frac{1}{2}ε=21​, then there exists an NNN so that if n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, then d(xn,x)<12d\p{x_n, x} < \frac{1}{2}d(xn​,x)<21​. But ddd is the discrete metric, so the only way this can occur is if d(xn,x)=0d\p{x_n, x} = 0d(xn​,x)=0, i.e., xn=xx_n = xxn​=x. Thus, we have shown that if n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, then xn=xx_n = xxn​=x, which was what we wanted to show.
